Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Does Leaf Function Evolve in the Invaded Range? A study of East Asian Forest Invaders in Japan and North America
Award.AbstractNarration:
Invasive plant species from East Asia are becoming increasingly abundant in North American forests, and often have negative impacts on forest function and biodiversity. Differences in how East Asian and North American plants acquire energy may explain the invasiveness of East Asian species. This project will examine differences in leaf traits driving energy capture in invasive species in their native (East Asia) and invasive ranges (North America). Seedlings of East Asian maple, cherry, and honeysuckle species growing in Aobayama Botanical Garden in Sendai, Japan will be used as focal individuals. A replicate study will be completed in Syracuse, NY using individuals sourced from North American populations. This project is a collaboration with Dr. Kouki Hikosaka, an accomplished ecophysiologist at Tohoku University in Sendai, Japan. The results of this study will allow land managers to more efficiently minimize negative impacts of invasive species, an endeavor in which large amounts of resources and labor are invested annually.

Plant invaders native to East Asia are increasingly abundant in Eastern North American (ENA) forests. The goal of this project is to understand leaf-level physiological strategies used by shade tolerant, invasive woody species (representatives from maple, cherry, and honeysuckle species to maximize carbon assimilation at different light levels. Physiological comparisons will involve invasive and non-invasive species, as well as population-level variation in non-native species across their native and invasive ranges. This project will also quantify potential costs of being able to adjust leaf physiology to changes in light environments (i.e. from deep shade to high light after gap formation). Understanding the costs and benefits of physiological strategies at both the species and population levels will broaden our understanding of the mechanisms invaders use to outcompete native species. This project is a collaborative effort with Dr. Kouki Hikosaka at Tohoku University, a prominent leaf function expert.

This award under the East Asia and Pacific Summer Institutes program supports summer research by a U.S. graduate student and is jointly funded by NSF and the Japan Society for the Promotion of Science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Invasive species are species not native to the habitat in which they are found, and are instead from another continent. In recent years, invasive species have become increasingly prevalent in the deeply shaded understories of Eastern North American (ENA) forests. Quite frequently, invasive species are more capable than native plants at tolerating the extremely low sunlight levels found in ENA forests, which gives them a competitive advantage relative to native understory species. Due to this increased success in deep shade, invasive species can easily dominate a forest understory in a few years if left unmanaged, decreasing habitat diversity for native and threatened animals and plants. This project aims to understand the ways that shade-tolerant invasive species capture energy, to understand differences in energy capture between populations of invasive species in their native and invasive ranges, and to understand differences between invasive species and co-occurring native species. By understanding differences in energy capture traits, we can improve the management techniques used by foresters and natural areas managers.

Plants capture energy via leaves, and total energy capture is often determined by the total amount of sunlight that a plant receives, but certain species are more efficient in their sunlight capture and use than others, and can thus capture relatively more energy given the same resources. We hypothesized that differences in resource use between native and invasive plants may explain the apparent competitive advantage that invasive species have in the shady understory of many Northeastern forests. Additionally, studying invasive species in their native range (East Asia), allows us to pinpoint specific traits that may have been selected for upon species transport to their new ranges that increase energy capture relative to native species. We measured energy capture traits of leaves of ENA invaders in East Asia (home range) during summer 2016 in forests in Sendai, Japan, and the same traits of the same species (in the invasive, away range) will be measured in ENA in 2017. In total, five ENA invasive species native to Japan were chosen for this study. In 2017, we will measure traits of co-occurring shade tolerant ENA species for comparison to invaders from both continents. Our preliminary analysis of data collected from plants in Japan suggests that invasive species are capable of adapting leaf traits to reflect a variety of light environments, suggesting they may have been “predisposed” to become successful invaders of many types of habitats before they were even transported to ENA. The selected ENA invasive species have varying levels of resource use efficiencies, suggesting other environmental variables, such as soil quality or mycorrhizal symbionts, may impact invasive species success in the away range.

Another goal of this project was to provide the PI with research and cultural experience in a foreign research setting. This aspect of the project was highly successful, since the PI was placed in a Japanese ecophysiology lab at Tohoku University (advised by Dr. Kouki Hikosaka) for the duration of summer 2016, and was exposed to a much different academic culture. The PI had to learn to be adaptable in an unfamiliar place and open to new ways of conducting science, and she found this highly beneficial. Overall, the experience gained from this EAPSI award will help her greatly with future research and career endeavors.
